Theory

theory.Rmd


üéØ Motivations

Characterizing interactions between drugs is an area of major interest for drug
development, as exploiting synergism between drugs could allow increasing treatment efficacy using lower doses of single drugs, and avoiding antagonistic interaction is needed to maintain the therapeutic efficacy of drugs. Broadly speaking, synergism and antagonism could be defined as an increase or a reduction of the effect of a drug combination compared to the effect expected for the combination on the basis of the single agent effects.

The EDITH package enables the synergistic effects of two or three drugs to be explored, based on cell viability data obtained from combination experiments. The package is designed to analyze and visualize drug interactions and implements a widely used method for assessing drug interactions: the Bliss independence model.

üìê Bliss independence model

The Bliss independence model is a mathematical framework used to evaluate the independence (ie. the absence of any interaction effect) of two drugs when they are administered in combination. The general form of Bliss independence model is the following equation:

Ecombined=EA+EB‚àí(EA*EB)E_{combined} = E_A + E_B - (E_A * E_B) where:

  • EAE_A is the effect of drug A,
  • EBE_B is the effect of drug B,
  • EcombinedE_{combined} is the expected effect of the drug combination.

In the case of a cancer cell population, the effect will correspond to the fraction of cells killed by the drug(s). For example, if drug A kills 30% of the cells, EA=0.3E_A = 0.3 and drug B kills 40% of the cells EB=0.4E_B = 0.4. According to the Bliss independence model, the expected effect of the combination of drugs A and B would be: Ecombined=0.3+0.4‚àí(0.3*0.4)=0.58E_{combined} = 0.3 + 0.4 - (0.3 * 0.4) = 0.58 This means that the combination of drugs A and B is expected to kill 58% of the cells if they act independently.

The Bliss equation can be recast in terms of unaffected cells as follows:

Ucombined=UA*UBU_{combined} = U_A * U_B

where:

  • UAU_A is the fraction of unaffected cells by drug A (ie. viability after treatment with drug A),
  • UBU_B is the fraction of unaffected cells by drug B (ie. viability after treatment with drug B),
  • UcombinedU_{combined} is the expected fraction of unaffected cells by the drug combination.

For example, if drug A leaves 70% of the cells unaffected, UA=0.7U_A = 0.7 and drug B leaves 60% of the cells unaffected UB=0.6U_B = 0.6. According to the Bliss independence model, the expected fraction of unaffected cells by the combination of drugs A and B would be:

Ucombined=0.7*0.6=0.42U_{combined} = 0.7 * 0.6 = 0.42 This means that the combination of drugs A and B is expected to leave 42% of the cells unaffected if they act independently.

The generalized form of the Bliss equation for a combination of n drugs is:

Ucombined=‚àèi=1nUiU_{combined} = \prod_{i=1}^n U_i

where:

  • i=1,...,ni = 1, ..., n indexes the drugs in the combination,
  • UiU_i is the fraction of unaffected cells by drug ii.

La formule de Bliss est utilis√©e pour √©valuer l‚Äôadditivit√© des effets de deux ou plusieurs m√©dicaments lorsqu‚Äôils sont administr√©s en combinaison. Elle repose sur l‚Äôid√©e que si deux m√©dicaments agissent ind√©pendamment l‚Äôun de l‚Äôautre, l‚Äôeffet combin√© devrait √™tre √©gal √† la somme des effets individuels de chaque m√©dicament. La formule de Bliss est g√©n√©ralement exprim√©e comme suit :

En d‚Äôautres termes, si les m√©dicaments A et B sont administr√©s s√©par√©ment, leurs effets individuels sont additionn√©s, mais l‚Äôeffet combin√© est ajust√© en soustrayant le produit de leurs effets individuels. La formule de Lehar est utilis√©e pour √©valuer l‚Äôefficacit√© des combinaisons de m√©dicaments en tenant compte de leur interaction. Elle est souvent utilis√©e dans le contexte de la pharmacologie pour quantifier l‚Äôeffet d‚Äôune combinaison de m√©dicaments par rapport √† leurs effets individuels. La formule de Lehar est g√©n√©ralement exprim√©e comme suit : CI = (E_A * E_B) / E_combined o√π : - CI est l‚Äôindice de combinaison, qui quantifie l‚Äôinteraction entre les m√©dicaments. - E_A est l‚Äôeffet du m√©dicament A. - E_B est l‚Äôeffet du m√©dicament B. - E_combined est l‚Äôeffet combin√© des deux m√©dicaments lorsqu‚Äôils sont administr√©s ensemble. L‚Äôindice de combinaison (CI) est utilis√© pour √©valuer si l‚Äôeffet combin√© des m√©dicaments est sup√©rieur, inf√©rieur ou √©gal √† la somme de leurs effets individuels. Elle permet aux chercheurs de mieux comprendre comment les m√©dicaments interagissent entre eux et d‚Äôoptimiser les sch√©mas th√©rapeutiques.

Method:

Index:

According to the approach proposed by Lehar (Leh√°r et al., 2007, 2008, 2009), a point-by-point calculation of the expected values in case of absence of interaction effect is performed over all the matrix concentration combinations in order to obtain an expected-value matrix. Then, a combination index, CI, is calculated as follows: CI=lnfAlnfB‚àëA,B(M0‚àíME)CI = \ln f_A \ln f_B \sum_{A,B} (M_0 - M_E) where MOM_O and MEM_E are the matrices of the observed and expected values, respectively, and fAf_A and fBf_B are the dilution factors for the drugs A and B. The CI is a positive-gated, effect-weighted volume over the lack of interaction effect (i.e.¬†Bliss independence), adjusted for variable dilution factors fAf_A and fBf_B. An efficacy index is also calculated as follow: EI=lnfAlnfB‚àëA,BM0EI = \ln f_A \ln f_B \sum_{A,B} M_0.

Leh√°r, J., Zimmermann, G.R., Krueger, A.S., Molnar, R.A., Ledell, J.T., Heilbut, A.M., Short, G.F., Giusti, L.C., Nolan, G.P., Magid, O.A., et al.¬†(2007). Chemical combination effects predict connectivity in biological systems. Mol. Syst. Biol. 3, 80.

Leh√°r, J., Stockwell, B.R., Giaever, G., and Nislow, C. (2008). Combination chemical genetics. Nat. Chem. Biol. 4, 674‚Äì681.

Leh√°r, J., Krueger, A.S., Avery, W., Heilbut, A.M., Johansen, L.M., Price, E.R., Rickles, R.J., Short, G.F., Staunton, J.E., Jin, X., et al.¬†(2009). Synergistic drug combinations tend to improve therapeutically relevant selectivity. Nat. Biotechnol. 27, 659‚Äì666.

Note: MOM_O et MEM_E correspondent aux nombres de cellules mortes (et pas vivantes comme dans nos calculs ‚Ä¶)
